messages: f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (12:44): what are the reasons again for not using iso8601? http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web 62c428533830d84fd8bc77bf402512fcps/current-work/multipage/infrastructure.html#valid-date-string # someone i think has told me this before, but I forgot :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:46): f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678: Do you mean using the whole of ISO 8601, or a subset of it?
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (12:46): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: either or
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (12:47): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: i guess html5 define a subset as the whole thing is too complex?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:47): (based on about zero knowledge) would guess that the whole of ISO 8601 is too complex a thing to require, and what's in the spec maybe is a compatible subset
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (12:48): ok, sounds familiar
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:48): iirc iso8601 allows crazy things like comments
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:48): Also I'd guess (based on never having read it or anything so I'm probably wrong) ISO 8601 doesn't define how to parse invalid strings
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:54): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: No, it doesn't
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:54): f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678: Backwards compatible
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:54): f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678: Stuff already uses whitespace instead of "T" for example
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:54): Also, ISO8601 allows three different forms for the date
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:55): (Which is stupid because nobody cares about any 62c428533830d84fd8bc77bf402512fcart from YYYYMMDD)
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (12:55): thanks guys! i need to write a little blog entry next
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:58): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: You mean nobody except for everybody who cares about dd/mm/yyyy and mm/dd/yyyy etc?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:02): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, people who care about using dd/mm/yyyy and mm/dd/yyyy can be ignored because those formats are annoyingly ambiguous

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:05): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: It is easier just to ignore people who use mm/dd/yyyy since that is crazy. dd/mm/yyyy is only marginally worse than yyyymmdd
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:06): will use yyyy-dd-mm from now on just to confuse everyone
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:08): mmyyyydd ftw
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:08): I like ymydymyd
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (13:08): mydymyd is better
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:09): How about mydyrmydy, where 'r' stands for a random digit?
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (13:20): blogs http://dabase.com/blog/HTML5_is8601/
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:22): f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678: a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 says it doesn't allow comments
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:22): so i was probably thinking of something else, like email addresses
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:25): or media types, wtf
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:25): http://hydracen.com/dx/iso8601.htm

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:31): ja

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:47): hmm? <ruby> is one of the escape-foreign-lands tags?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:54): i wonder how much would break if we make that list empty
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:55): i.e. never escape
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:57): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: yeah, foster parenting text sucks
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:57): I just gave my HTML5 lecture
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:57): time to see if the recording is any good
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:59): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I mostly didn't get mixed up in my words and I got a few questions
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:00): any interesting questions?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:00): the questions were about when can HTML5 features be used, are there JS implementations, relationship of new elements to microformats and RDFa, extensibility
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:01): fun :)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:01): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: also see earlier in the logs; i've broken v.nu (nothing will validate until you restart the service)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:02): good thing my demos were all playback and didn't rely on live services working
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:03): http://html5.validator.nu/?doc=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.whatwg.org WFM
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:03): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: http://validator.nu/?doc=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.whatwg.org
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:04): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: i only validated <isindex> on v.nu, not h.v.nu
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:04): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: they're different instances, right?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:04): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: aah. yeah. I've fixed this bug in svn.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:04): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: yes, different instances
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:05): http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=446
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:06): what happened was that the singleton that represents empty attributes accidentally got attributes added to it
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:06): why did that affect <body>?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:13): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: if there was a body without attributes, the empty attributes singleton got used
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:13): interesting
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:13): restarted with the same bogus code. uploading a fix now
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:13): no questions about why we didn't use XForms and such?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:14): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: the exercise for the course relies on server-side XForms--not client side
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:14): (with Orbeon)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:14): ok
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:15): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: thanks for finding the bug. I thought it only affected the buffered mode--not the streaming mode
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:24): now, to distribute the recording of my lecture in a proper HTML5 <video> dogfood fashion, I should encode it as Theora...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:24): wants a Thusnelda build of XiphQT or ffmpeg2theora
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:29): wonders if there is a term for a single, unmached codepoint that is supposed to form a surrogate pair
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:30): I guess. Or simply "surrogate"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:30): surrogate character?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:31): nm
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:31): http://blogs.msdn.com/michkap/archive/2005/07/27/444101.aspx
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:32): it's a surrogate code point
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:33): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: There aren't any codepoints that are supposed to form a surrogate pair

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:34): There's just codepoints that happen to be numerically equal to some of the values used by UTF-16 to encode surrogates, but those codepoints are not supposed to be anything at all :-)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:35): suggests using the term "U+D800..U+DFFF"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:35): that's a range
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:35): suggests using the term "a codepoint in the range U+D800..U+DFFF"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:37): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: The Unicode FAQ uses the term surrogate code point
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:37): at least when encoded as UTF-16 they are code *units*
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:40): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Sure, but "a codepoint in the range U+D800..U+DFFF" might be clearer/obviouser depending on the context and audience
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:40): can imagine people interpreting "surrogate code point" as meaning "a code point that has to be represented using surrogates" or something like that
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:44): eww. my microphone sucked
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:45): my words are comprehensible, but it sounds like I'm in some kind of muffled container

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:48): (maybe because the parser tries to insert stuff into something that has been garbage collected)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:54): i think firefox is correct for that test
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:54): (the second script isn't executed because the script is not inserted to the document)

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:44): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: I'll have to look into that. thanks
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:44): is there a way to debug XHR serialization without an echoing script?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:46): "Or, if this fails because the Document cannot be serialized act as if data  is null."
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:46): I want to see when that happens
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:46): starts live HTTP headers
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:48): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: the spec should be clearer on when a documunt cannot be serialized
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:48): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: it seems that "xmlns:dublincore" local name in no namespace serializes in Gecko
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:52): the idea is that the spec uses the same serialization tricks as HTML5 for XML
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:52): unless the content is HTML in which case it uses the HTML serialization tricks
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:57): "</head><!>" puts the comment after head
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:58): but "</body><!>" doesn't put the comment after body
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:58): why this assymetry?
